abacus: A counting device that uses beads on rods to perform arithmetic operations.
amiable: Having or displaying a friendly and pleasant manner.
altruistic: Showing a selfless concern for the well-being of others.
bucolic: Relating to the pleasant aspects of the countryside and rural life.
beleaguer: To besiege or surround with hostile forces.
cacophony: A harsh, discordant mixture of sounds.
cloying: Disgustingly or excessively sweet or sentimental.
dichotomy: A division or contrast between two things that are or are represented as being opposed or entirely different.
disparate: Essentially different in kind; not allowing comparison.
ephemeral: Lasting for a very short time.
eclectic: Deriving ideas, styles, or tastes from a broad and diverse range of sources.
facetious: Treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor.
furtive: Attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt or a belief that discovery would lead to trouble.
garrulous: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
histrionic: Overly theatrical or melodramatic in character or style.
heterogeneous: Consisting of elements that are not of the same kind or nature.
idiosyncrasy: A mode of behavior or way of thought peculiar to an individual.
indelible: Not able to be forgotten or removed.
juxtapose: To place close together for contrasting effect.
jocular: Characterized by joking and good humor.
kaleidoscope: A constantly changing pattern or sequence of elements.
kowtow: To act in an excessively subservient manner.
labyrinth: A complicated irregular network of passages or paths in which it is difficult to find one's way.
lugubrious: Looking or sounding sad and dismal.
mellifluous: Sweet or musical; pleasant to hear.
myriad: A countless or extremely great number.
nuance: A subtle difference in or shade of meaning, expression, or sound.
nadir: The lowest point in the fortunes of a person or organization.
nepotism: The practice among those with power or influence of favoring relatives or friends, especially by giving them jobs.
obfuscate: To deliberately make something difficult to understand.
onerous: Involving a great deal of effort, trouble, or difficulty.
ostentatious: Characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; designed to impress or attract notice.
paragon: A person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality.
pernicious: Having a harmful effect, especially in a gradual or subtle way.
plethora: A large or excessive amount of something.
quintessential: Representing the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class.
quagmire: A soft boggy area of land that gives way underfoot.
resplendent: Attractive and impressive through being richly colorful or sumptuous.
reverie: A state of being pleasantly lost in one's thoughts; a daydream.
serendipity: The occurrence of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way.
soliloquy: An act of speaking one's thoughts aloud when by oneself or regardless of any hearers, especially by a character in a play.
supercilious: Behaving or looking as though one thinks one is superior to others.
tantamount: Equivalent in seriousness to; virtually the same as.
truculent: Eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant.
unilateral: Performed by or affecting only one person, group, or country involved in a particular situation, without the agreement of another or the others.
usurp: To take a position of power or importance illegally or by force.
vicarious: Experienced in the imagination through the feelings or actions of another person.
verisimilitude: The appearance of being true or real.
vociferous: Loud and forceful in making one's feelings known.
wistful: Having or showing a feeling of vague or regretful longing.
wily: Skilled at gaining an advantage, especially deceitfully.
wanton: Deliberate and unprovoked; sexually unrestrained or undisciplined.
xenophobe: A person who is fearful or hateful of anything foreign or strange.
xenial: Relating to hospitality or relations between host and guest.
zealous: Having or showing zeal; fervent, enthusiastic.
zenith: The highest point reached by a celestial or other object.
